Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for the workshop on Fluid-Structure Interaction Problems to be held at the National Center for Theoretical Sciences (NCTS) in Taiwan, May 26-29, 2011. The award will provide partial support for US participants, principally graduate students, post-doctoral researchers, and junior faculty.

The fluid-structure interaction problems arise in a variety of important applications in materials science, biological flows, and multi-phase flows among others. The workshop includes plenary lectures by international speakers on topics of current research interest in the area of fluid-structure interactions, including modeling and analysis, the related theory and analysis of partial differential equations, various numerical methods, and applications. It will provide a venue for the discussion of important recent advances and the current directions of research. The workshop encourages presentations by junior participants. It will serve to expose new research opportunities to young researchers and graduate students, and to facilitate the scientific collaborations between US scientists and their international counterpart. NCTS will support most of the expenses and logistics of the workshop.

Workshop web site: http://math.cts.nthu.edu.tw/Mathematics/FSIP2011.htm

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF grant was intended to support US participants to attend "Workshop  on  fluid-structure interaction problems" at the National Center for Theoretical Sciences (NCTS) in Taiwan, May 26-28, 2011. Altogether about 11 US participants were supported either fully or partially by this grant. The list included 6 females, one American Indian, one undergraduate student (female), two graduate students, one postdoctoral researcher, 3 assistant professors. Due to the earthquake in Japan in 2011, the airfare were cheaper than what was budgeted. Approved by the NSF, the PI used the remaining fund to support US participants to attend "The Second International Conference on Scientific Computing", Nanjing, China, May 22-25, 2012. We supported fully for one African American female graduate student, partially supported 4 other graduate students; 2 postdoctoral researchers, 2 assistant professors, a few associate and full professors. The PI was main organizer for both events. Both events had the theme of fluid-structure interactions as emphasized in the original proposal.

We feel that the workshop and the conference were effective to introduce some of these talented young researchers to a broader international community, to keep exposing new research opportunities to these young researchers and graduate/undergraduate students at international workshops, and to facilitate the scientific interactions between the young generation of US mathematicians and their international peers and international senior researchers. The workshop and the conference  also brought the visibility of the research by US speakers to a  broad international audience.
